text.p: These are the leading stories in the Pakistani press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- The federal government has asked the government of Sindh province to expedite supply of wheat to help overcome flour shortages in the provinces of Punjab and the North West Frontier Province.

- Hundreds of people, including women and children, attacked a tractor trolly carrying flour and looted as many as 600 20-kg bags in the city of Lahore in the Punjab province, and protestors in North West Frontier Province blocked roads and to demonstrate against the shortages.
- Foreign Minister Gohar Ayub Khan said Pakistan wished to continue talks with India for resolving all outstanding disputes, including the core issue of Kashmir.
- The Ministry of Health has framed new rules banning the sale of any drug if it was banned for sale in the U.S., European Union, Canada, Japan or Australia.
- Pakistani stock markets registered an outflow of $11 million in February following an inflow of $20 million in January.
- The Karachi Stock Exchange is seeking formal recognition from the Tokyo Stock Exchange as part of its effort to link itself with the outside world.
- Britian's Lasmo and National Power are actively working on a joint project to import liquified natural gas to Pakistan for power generation.
